author: By Michael Levenson
title: Portuguese Police to Renew Search for British Girl Missing Since 2007
description: The case of 3-year-old Madeleine McCann, who disappeared while vacationing with her family in Portugal, has drawn international attention for years.
content: The police in Portugal said on Monday that they planned to resume the search for a British child who vanished in the country’s Algarve region in 2007, renewing international attention on the disappearance of Madeleine McCann.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $4.2 Million Homes in California
description: A midcentury-modern house in Los Angeles, a 1937 cottage in Laguna Beach and a 2021 home in Hermosa Beach.
content: This house was designed by the well-regarded architects A. Quincy Jones and Whitney R. Smith for a housing cooperative established by a group of musicians in postwar Los Angeles. Few of the planned homes were actually built, and this one had fallen into disrepair when the owners bought it in 2021 and proceeded to restore it to its original condition.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Reyburn
title: At Antwerp Art Weekend, Collectors Buy With Their Gut
description: The Belgian city doesn’t have a huge dealer base, nor is it home to as many artists as other major centers. But it has a tradition of art buying that goes back to Rubens and Breughel.
content: “At art fairs, people look too quickly,” said Jason Poirier dit Caulier, the founder and director of the Plus-One Gallery in Antwerp, Belgium. “Here they take a bit more time. They almost want to touch,” he added.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Crevar
title: To Find Europe’s Best Bike Routes, a Cycling Writer Asked the Crowd
description: The longtime sports journalist Claude Droussent discusses his new guidebook to cycling in Europe, which uses data from the fitness app Strava, and the growing role bicycles play in worldwide travel.
content: When it came time to put together “Cycling Atlas Europe,” a new guidebook detailing 350 single-day rides across the continent, the sportswriter and cycling expert Claude Droussent, 65, knew where to turn: Strava, a fitness app that lets cyclists (and runners and hikers) record their routes with GPS and then share them with each other, and that calls itself “the largest sports community in the world.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser
title: Foo Fighters Introduce Josh Freese as Their New Drummer
description: Freese, a veteran musician, appeared with the rock band ahead of its upcoming tour and album release, the first since its drummer, Taylor Hawkins, died last year.
content: The Foo Fighters introduced a new drummer, Josh Freese, just before the release of their album next month and their first tour since the death last year of the rock band’s previous drummer, Taylor Hawkins, which devastated the group and its fans.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: How Did an Obscure City Become China’s Hottest Spot? Barbecue.
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 22, 2023.
content: “To see all this liveliness, after three years of the pandemic, my heart feels pretty warm.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Riley Mellen
title: Attackers Hit Russian Border Towns; Anti-Putin Russians Say They Did It
description: The local Russian governor blamed a Ukrainian sabotage group, while Kyiv’s military intelligence agency said “opposition-minded citizens of Russia” were responsible.
content: Clashes broke out on Monday in Russian villages near the Ukrainian border, according to local officials and verified videos, after a group of anti-Kremlin Russian fighters allied with Ukraine appeared to have mounted a rare ground assault inside Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: ‘Succession’ Season 4, Episode 9 Recap: Dearly Departed
description: This week, Logan Roy’s family and associates gather for his funeral, pausing all grudges so they can pay conflicted respects to the man.
content: When people talk about TV or movies as visual medium, they’re usually referring to pretty pictures or striking compositions. But you know what’s also an important part of visual storytelling? The simple reaction shot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker and Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Idaho Murder Suspect Declines to Enter Plea
description: Bryan Kohberger, the former Ph.D. student accused of killing four University of Idaho students, appeared in court Monday after being indicted on murder charges.
content: The man accused of murdering four college students during a predawn intrusion at their house near the University of Idaho declined to enter a plea to the charges Monday, electing to “stand silent” during the first step in what promises to be a lengthy legal process.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Museler
title: Buddy Melges, American Sailing Champion, Dies at 93
description: A product of a Wisconsin lake region, he was the first sailor to win both Olympic gold and sailing’s top prize, the America’s Cup. And his colleagues revered him.
content: Buddy Melges, a Wisconsin native who became the first sailor to win both an Olympic gold medal and the sport’s top prize, the America’s Cup, died on Thursday at his home in Fontana, Wis., on the western shore of Geneva Lake. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Yellen Warns Again That the U.S. Could Default as Soon as June 1
description: The so-called X-date could still come as early as next week.
content: Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen reiterated on Monday that the United States could be unable to pay its bills as soon as June 1, an announcement that maintains pressure on the White House and congressional leaders as they negotiate how to raise the nation’s debt limit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Glorioso and Nicholas Nehamas
title: How DeSantis Is Trying to Lure Older Voters Away From Trump
description: The Florida governor is courting the large, politically influential group by pointing to his efforts to lower prescription drug prices. But his pitch can be lost on some voters.
content: As a 44-year-old member of Generation X, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida might be an unlikely candidate to wrest his party’s older voters away from Donald J. Trump, a 76-year-old baby boomer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: The Castle Where Future Queens Drop the Royal Act
description: At Atlantic College, a school in a 12th-century castle clinging to the windy Welsh coastline, teenage royals take classes on world peace.
content: The rolling green lawns of a 12th-century castle perched on a windy stretch of south Wales coastline usually dotted with sheep hosted not one but two kings of Europe last weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sharon Otterman and Yana Paskova
title: A Movement to Make Workplaces ‘Menopause Friendly’
description: What is a menopause-friendly workplace? Women in cities like New York may soon find out, as U.S. companies adopt practices that were already spreading in Britain.
content: In the last few years, managers at Nvidia, the global computer graphics company, began hearing a new kind of complaint: Some of their female employees were struggling with hot flashes, fatigue and brain fog — common symptoms of the menopause transition — and their regular doctors weren’t offering guidance or relief.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Succession’ Finale and Starry Rom-Coms
description: The HBO hit wraps up its series run, and Amy Schumer’s “Trainwreck” airs.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, May 22-28. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer, Maggie Haberman and Ben Protess
title: Prosecutors Sought Records on Trump’s Foreign Business Deals Since 2017
description: The special counsel scrutinizing the former president’s handling of classified documents issued a subpoena to the Trump Organization seeking records related to seven countries.
content: Federal prosecutors overseeing the investigation into former President Donald J. Trump’s handling of classified documents have issued a subpoena for information about Mr. Trump’s business dealings in foreign countries since he took office, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: Rick Hoyt, Who Competed in Races With His Father, Dies at 61
description: Hoyt regularly raced in the Boston Marathon with his father, Dick Hoyt, who pushed his wheelchair.
content: Rick Hoyt, a regular at the Boston Marathon who competed in more than a thousand road races using a wheelchair pushed by his father, died on Monday. He was 61.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Gutierrez
title: Fire Guts Manila’s Historic Post Office Building
description: Built in 1926, the structure is one of the Philippine capital’s most recognizable landmarks. The cause of the fire was unclear on Monday.
content: The Manila Central Post Office, one of the Philippine capital’s most historic buildings, was all but destroyed by fire overnight, officials said on Monday morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: College Graduates, Too, Are Fleeing California’s Big Cities
description: A New York Times analysis finds that it isn’t just low-wage workers who are being priced out.
content: California is expensive — that’s no secret.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Rovner
title: The Two Michael Rovners
description: A writer meets his double.
content: I first became aware of the other Michael Rovner nearly five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David McCabe and Sapna Maheshwari
title: TikTok Sues Montana, Calling State Ban Unconstitutional
description: The Chinese-owned video app filed the lawsuit days after Montana’s governor signed the ban, which takes effect on Jan. 1, into law.
content: TikTok on Monday sued to block Montana from banning the popular video app, escalating its efforts to stop a prohibition that would be the first of its kind in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Carmelo Anthony Announces Retirement After 19 N.B.A. Seasons
description: Anthony, known as one of the top scorers in league history, had struggled in recent years and did not play the 2022-23 season.
content: Carmelo Anthony, the former Knicks star and one of the greatest scorers in N.B.A. history, announced his retirement on Monday, calling the farewell after 19 seasons “bittersweet.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Welfare Debate Stalling the Debt Talks
description: Work requirements are popular, but there’s a thin line between motivation and punishment.
content: To hear House Speaker Kevin McCarthy talk, Republicans are doing poor people a favor by seeking to impose or expand work requirements for recipients of social welfare programs. He and others argue that recipients who are pushed out of their comfort zones will get jobs and put themselves on the road to the middle class. “Assistance programs are supposed to be temporary, not permanent,” he said in a speech at the New York Stock Exchange in April. “A hand up, not a handout. A bridge to independence, not a barrier.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: The Republican Presidential Plot Is Thickening
description: Tim Scott and Ron DeSantis are on the near horizon.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. It looks like we’ll be getting two new campaign launches soon in the race for the Republican presidential nomination: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina and Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida. Any free advice you want to offer them on how they can beat you-know-who?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kyle Buchanan
title: How Scorsese, DiCaprio and De Niro Made ‘Killers of the Flower Moon’
description: In this true-life crime tale, they focused not on the investigators but on the evildoers, and made the Osage woman played by Lily Gladstone central.
content: Films can take years to make, and at age 80, the director Martin Scorsese is aware he has a finite amount of both films and years left.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: A Mother Smoked Weed. New York Moved to Put Her Baby in Foster Care.
description: The case illustrates the uncertainty some agencies face about marijuana policies now that the drug is legal.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the case of a Bronx woman who smoked marijuana — legally — before giving birth, only to have the city tell the hospital not to let her take the baby home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Learn Korean Tea Ceremony Etiquette With a Tea Master
description: Sip tea or purchase some to go at Genesis House Restaurant, pick up a lavender cream mille crêpe cake from Lady M, and more food news.
content: Genesis House, the Manhattan flagship for the Korean automobile company that last year opened its restaurant Genesis House Restaurant Curated by Onjium, now has a serene tea pavilion in its building where Korean teas — green, red, black, blue, white and herbal — are served and available for purchase. Now, on Saturdays and Sundays there at 1 p.m., a tea master, Ashley Lim, is conducting traditional tea ceremonies for up to six guests. Described as less formal than a Japanese or Chinese routine, it involves learning the etiquette of darye, as the Korean tea ceremony is called, and sampling three teas, with snacks. The sessions will take place every weekend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanne Timmons
title: A Saber-Toothed Predator From Long Before Evolution Came Up With Cats
description: As an extinction crisis wiped out species at the end of the Permian Period, a predatory species emerged that dominated Southern Africa’s domain.
content: Some 252 million years ago, it was a disastrous time to be alive. Erupting supervolcanoes destabilized ecosystems, plunging the planet’s living things into a series of extinctions over the course of a million years and permanently changing life on Earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker and David E. Sanger
title: Biden Sees Coming ‘Thaw’ With China, Even as He Rallies Allies Against Beijing
description: During the Group of 7 meeting that just wrapped up, President Biden forged a consensus approach toward China despite tensions between the major powers over their approach.
content: President Biden and his allies spent much of the G7 summit in Hiroshima, Japan, announcing new arms packages for Ukraine, including a pathway to providing F-16 fighter planes. They spent hours discussing strategy with President Volodymyr Zelensky for the next phase of a hot war started by Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: For Diners With Deep Pockets, Dallas Is the New Dubai
description: The city’s booming economy is attracting a flock of luxury restaurants from other cities. Is that a good thing for local cuisine?
content: The crowds streaming into Highland Park Village are hungry for luxury. At this open-air shopping center in suburban Dallas, they valet-park their Porsches, sport Yves Saint Laurent handbags, flit in and out of Audemars Piguet and pause for brunch at Sadelle’s, the fancy new deli from Major Food Group in New York.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Supreme Court Criticism
description: Democrats used to criticize the Supreme Court respectfully. Increasingly, they see the court as irredeemable.
content: During periods of intense political debate in the U.S., the Supreme Court often becomes a target of harsh criticism.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: The QR-Code Menu Is Being Shown the Door
description: A dining innovation that once looked like the future has worn out its welcome with many restaurateurs, customers and servers who say it takes the joy out of dining.
content: Heavenly Buffaloes, a chain of restaurants with locations in three North Carolina college towns, would seem tailor-made for QR-code menus. Its customers tend to be young and tech-savvy. Most come in hungry, many tipsy. And the menu isn’t exactly complicated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg and Monique Jaques
title: Welcome to the Era of W.N.B.A. Superteams. New Stars Need Not Apply.
description: The Liberty have a stacked roster and championship ambitions. But where are all the rookies?
content: The Liberty began their much hyped season as the newest superteam on the block, winning their home opener against the Indiana Fever, 90- 73.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: ‘Succession’ Style, Episode 9: The Funeral
description: Marcia looks “chic” for the funeral, and Matsson follows decorum for once, but the wives and mistresses steal the show.
content: This article contains spoilers for Episode 9 of the final season of “Succession.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: After the Warhol Decision, Another Major Copyright Case Looms
description: Richard Prince, an artist who appropriates images like Andy Warhol did, is being sued. But experts said the Supreme Court’s Warhol ruling may have little impact on the case.
content: For years, Andy Warhol and Richard Prince have been known as two of the art world’s most famous copiers, boundary-pushing appropriators whose use of other people’s images in their work has been scrutinized in court cases as the blurry line of copyright law is continually redrawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: Sinn Fein Surges in Local Elections, Highlighting Northern Ireland’s Divide
description: As the party climbs, its rivals, the Democratic Unionists, are stalled, which means any compromise that could revive its power-sharing national government may remain elusive.
content: The Irish nationalist party, Sinn Fein, cemented its status as the largest party in Northern Ireland in local election results counted over the weekend. But rather than break a political deadlock in the North, Sinn Fein’s striking gains may harden the sectarian divide that has long complicated its fragile government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag
title: Despite Migrant Arrivals, There’s No Shortage of Hotel Rooms in New York
description: The mayor has said the influx of migrants staying in hotel rooms could affect tourism, but about 20,500 hotel rooms remain unoccupied.
content: Thousands of migrants have come to New York City in the past two weeks, fueling what Mayor Eric Adams called “one of the great humanitarian crises” in the city’s history, as officials struggle to find places to house them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Liao
title: A.I. May Help Design Your Favorite Video Game Character
description: Generative A.I. is already changing how games are made, with Blizzard Entertainment training an image generator on assets from World of Warcraft, Diablo and Overwatch.
content: Intrigued by the potential that generative artificial intelligence holds for video game design, the studio Blizzard Entertainment has trained an image generator on its own hit titles. By feeding assets like the combative orcs of World of Warcraft, the macabre dungeons of Diablo and the vivacious heroes of Overwatch into the machine, Blizzard can effortlessly produce concept art for new ideas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg and Wyatt Orme
title: Ron DeSantis’s Takeover of a Progressive College
description: What Michelle Goldberg saw in Florida.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida is expected to enter the race for the Republican presidential nomination this week. Much of the narrative around him has focused on who he isn’t — Donald Trump. But DeSantis has also claimed the national spotlight for his role in the culture wars. In Florida, he has made education a preferred battleground, carrying out “Don’t Say Gay” policies in public schools and taking over the board of New College, a small public liberal arts institution in Sarasota. The Opinion columnist Michelle Goldberg has been tracking the changes there, and says that DeSantis’s vision for New College speaks volumes about his vision for America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: JPMorgan May Face New Questions About Succession
description: Revelations about rivals’ plans may prompt the bank’s shareholders to ask about who will replace Jamie Dimon at an annual investor gathering on Monday.
content: JPMorgan Chase will hold its investor day on Monday after one of the busiest starts to a year that the bank has had in some time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Farnaz Fassihi
title: Iran Ousts Top Security Official Tainted by Spy Scandal
description: Ali Shamkhani was one of the most powerful men in Iran, but it was not enough to insulate him after a close associate was accused of selling information to Britain.
content: Iran on Monday removed its top national security official, one of the most powerful men in the country, after he came under scrutiny over his close ties with a high-ranking British spy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Reinhart
title: The F.D.A.’s Birth Control Decision and Breaking the Medical Monopoly Over Health
description: The F.D.A. has an important decision to make.
content: An advisory panel at the Food and Drug Administration this month unanimously recommended that a contraceptive pill, Opill, be made available over the counter. The F.D.A. will decide this summer whether to follow this recommendation‌ — if it does, the United States will join over 100 other countries that have already approved oral contraceptives for use without a prescription. ‌
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kris Rhim
title: Brittney Griner Returns to the W.N.B.A. With a Weekend of Celebration
description: Griner, the Phoenix Mercury center, played in her first two official games since was freed from prison. She didn’t win either, but the moment meant far more than that.
content: PHOENIX — The public address announcer paused before introducing the final player in the Mercury’s starting lineup on Sunday. The song “Coming Home” by Skylar Grey began to play, and then Brittney Griner appeared on a red carpet with tall video screens behind her, an entrance befitting a rock star.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser
title: E. Jean Carroll Seeks New Damages From Trump for Comments on CNN
description: The former president’s repeated denials that he sexually abused Ms. Carroll “show the depth of his malice” and merit heavy damages, her lawyer wrote.
content: E. Jean Carroll, who this month won $5 million in damages from former President Donald J. Trump, is now seeking a “very substantial” additional amount in response to his insults on a CNN program just a day after she won her sexual abuse and defamation case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Luke Vander Ploeg, Michael Simon Johnson, Clare Toeniskoetter, Carlos Prieto, Caitlin O'Keefe, Rachel Quester, Lisa Tobin, Anita Badejo, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Is Trump’s Nomination Now Inevitable?
description: The 2022 midterms looked as if they might push Republicans to move on. But things have shifted.
content: Voters in the 2022 midterms seemed to send a clear message — a rejection of Trumpism and extremism. And yet it appears increasingly likely that he will win the Republican nomination for the 2024 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Dave Matthews Band’s Grown-Up View of Love and Dread
description: “Walk Around the Moon,” the group’s 10th album, faces troubles and searches for solace.
content: Dave Matthews Band albums seesaw between joy and angst. On the home front, with a partner and family, the songs find affection, pleasure and ease. Beyond it, the wider world holds strife and dread. And looking inward can be just as troubling.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catie Edmondson and Katie Rogers
title: Biden and McCarthy Describe ‘Productive’ Meeting, but No Agreement Is Reached
description: With the United States at risk of defaulting for the first time, Speaker Kevin McCarthy and President Biden met again but remained far apart on a deal.
content: President Biden and Speaker Kevin McCarthy expressed optimism on Monday that they could break the partisan stalemate that has prevented action to avert a default on the nation’s debt, but remained far apart on a deal to raise the debt limit as Democrats resisted Republicans’ demands for spending cuts in exchange.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Rick Wolff, Sports Radio Host and Much More, Is Dead at 71
description: As a psychological coach (and ex-player), he helped revive a woeful Cleveland baseball team. He had a WFAN show about youth sports and shepherded best sellers.
content: Rick Wolff’s résumé is about as long as a Major League roster, his disparate professions linked by an adoration of sports and a fascination with sports psychology.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Williams
title: Linda Lewis, British Singer Whose Voice Knew Few Limits, Dies at 72
description: Inspired by Motown early in her career, she became an acclaimed singer-songwriter and backed the likes of David Bowie, Rod Stewart and Cat Stevens.
content: Linda Lewis, a critically acclaimed soul singer and songwriter whose pyrotechnic voice propelled four Top 10 singles as a solo artist in her native Britain and led to work as a backup vocalist on acclaimed albums by stars like David Bowie, Cat Stevens and Rod Stewart, died on May 3 at her home in Waltham Abbey, outside London. She was 72.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How the Arts Can Benefit Your Mental Health (No Talent Required)
description: Drawing, music and writing can elevate your mood. Here are some easy ways to welcome them into your life.
content: When Dr. Frank Clark was in medical school studying to be a psychiatrist, he decided to write his first poem.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: Good Night, Sweet Prince
description: Our critic assesses the achievement of Martin Amis, Britain’s most famous literary son.
content: On May 6, at the age of 74, Charles III was crowned king of England. A few weeks later, at 73, Martin Amis died at his home in Florida. One event seemed almost comically belated, the other tragically premature. Charles took over the family business well past normal retirement age, while Amis was denied the illustrious dotage that great writers deserve.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Goldman
title: Justice Dept. Investigated Clinton Foundation Until Trump’s Final Days
description: President Donald J. Trump and his allies tried to cast the Clinton Foundation as corrupt. But the yearslong investigation sputtered to its conclusion without charges.
content: The Justice Department kept open the investigation into Hillary Clinton’s family foundation for nearly all of President Donald J. Trump’s administration, with prosecutors closing the case without charges just days before he left office.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: mantra
description: This word has appeared in 215 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word mantra has appeared in 215 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 21 in “Greenland Wants You to Visit. But Not All at Once” by Gabriel Leigh:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shannon Doyne
title: How Have Your Friends Helped You?
description: A writer says her friends “were a parachute” when she got divorced. How have you and your friends cared for one another in tough times?
content: When was the last time your friends helped you through something difficult? How did they show up for you? Did they check in regularly, write and deliver notes of encouragement, share a special treat at just the right time, or just sit quietly and listen to you vent? How did it feel to have someone you could depend on?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Book Removals May Have Violated Students’ Rights, Education Department Says
description: The U.S. Department of Education reached a settlement with a Georgia school district after launching an investigation into whether book removals created a hostile environment for students.
content: A Georgia school district may have violated its students’ civil rights by removing certain books from its libraries, creating a “hostile environment” for students based on race, sex or national origin, said the United States Department of Education.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
title: Erdogan Secures Endorsement of Former Rival for President
description: The support of Sinan Ogan gives the Turkish president a boost as he takes on the opposition leader Kemal Kilicdaroglu.
content: The candidate who came in third in Turkey’s presidential election last week announced on Monday that he was endorsing President Recep Tayyip Erdogan in the runoff vote on Sunday, granting Mr. Erdogan an additional boost against his remaining challenger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nico Grant and Kashmir Hill
title: Google’s Photo App Still Can’t Find Gorillas. And Neither Can Apple’s.
description: Eight years after a controversy over Black people being mislabeled as gorillas by image analysis software — and despite big advances in computer vision — tech giants still fear repeating the mistake.
content: When Google released its stand-alone Photos app in May 2015, people were wowed by what it could do: analyze images to label the people, places and things in them, an astounding consumer offering at the time. But a couple of months after the release, a software developer, Jacky Alciné, discovered that Google had labeled photos of him and a friend, who are both Black, as “gorillas,” a term that is particularly offensive because it echoes centuries of racist tropes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Companies Are Taking a Harder Line on Union Organizers, Workers Say
description: Apple, Starbucks, Trader Joe’s and REI are accused of targeting union supporters after organizing efforts gained traction, charges the companies deny.
content: After working for more than seven years at an Apple store in Kansas City, Mo., Gemma Wyatt ran into trouble.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Schwartz
title: After Writing About Mental Illness, Kay Redfield Jamison Turns to Healers
description: In “Fires in the Dark,” Jamison, known for her expertise on manic depression, delves into the quest to heal. Her new book, she says, is a “love song to psychotherapy.”
content: Kay Redfield Jamison arrives punctually at a towering marble statue of Jesus Christ in the entrance of the old hospital building on Johns Hopkins Medical Campus. Next to it, two guest books are left open to receive the wishes and prayers of those who pass through these halls. “Dear God please help our daughter feel better. …” “Dear Lord, please heal my grandpa and let him live happily. …”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: Andrew Tate Thought He Was Above the Law. Romania Proved Him Wrong.
description: The online influencer, popular with young men, is facing charges of human trafficking and rape, after seeking out a place where “corruption is accessible to everybody.”
content: Andrew Tate, a pugilistic online influencer and self-crowned “king of toxic masculinity,” never made any secret of why he had chosen Romania as his home and business base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joshua Barone
title: Review: ‘Stranger Love’ Reflects the L.A. Philharmonic at Its Finest
description: The premiere of Dylan Mattingly and Thomas Bartscherer’s six-hour opera was presented by the orchestra — an institution at an inflection point.
content: The composer Dylan Mattingly’s cheeks turned red, and he held a hand up to his eyes, as he began to cry late Saturday night during the bows for the world premiere of his opera “Stranger Love.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl and Andrew E. Kramer
title: Zelensky wraps up another fruitful trip and Russia claims a big win in Ukraine.
description: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine grabbed the spotlight at the Group of 7 summit in Japan and won even more pledges for military aid, including training for Ukraine’s pilots on F-16 fighter jets. But at home this week he faces questions about the future of the eastern city of Bakhmut, the deadliest battle of the war.
content: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine grabbed the spotlight at the Group of 7 summit in Japan and won even more pledges for military aid, including training for Ukraine’s pilots on F-16 fighter jets. But at home this week he faces questions about the future of the eastern city of Bakhmut, the deadliest battle of the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: The Sound of France’s Pension Fury? The Saucepan.
description: Protesters have been harassing the French government in clanky demonstrations that have gone viral in a country with no shortage of kitchenware.
content: Spreading across a highway so that no cars could pass, 100 or so protesters banged saucepans in a deafening racket that echoed through a remote valley outside the town of La-Cluse-et-Mijoux in eastern France last month. They were marching toward a nearby castle where the French president was due to arrive, determined to stand in his way and create cacophony around the visit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: With 11 Weeks at No. 1, Morgan Wallen Joins an Elite Club
description: The country star’s chart run with “One Thing at a Time” puts him in a league with Whitney Houston, Stevie Wonder and the “Titanic” soundtrack.
content: There was snow on the ground when Morgan Wallen’s “One Thing at a Time” arrived at No. 1 in early March. Now, in balmy late spring, the country superstar’s latest LP is racking up its 11th consecutive week on the chart — a feat that puts Wallen in the company of Whitney Houston and Stevie Wonder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Carper Says He Will Retire, Vacating Seat in Solidly Democratic Delaware
description: The fourth-term senator said he would do everything he could to ensure that Representative Lisa Blunt Rochester, the state’s lone congresswoman and his former intern, won the race to succeed him.
content: Senator Thomas R. Carper, a veteran Democrat from Delaware, announced on Monday that he would not seek re-election next year, opening up a seat in a deep-blue state that he said he hoped would go to his handpicked successor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Hicks and Marc Santora
title: Bakhmut Is Gone: An Aerial Look at the War’s Destruction
description: Drone footage taken by The New York Times captured the scorched buildings, destroyed schools and cratered parks that now define the city in eastern Ukraine.
content: Bakhmut is obliterated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: E.U. Asks Greece to Investigate Video Showing Migrants Abandoned at Sea
description: Citing a report by The Times, a top E.U. official said the Greek authorities had been urged to investigate after footage showed the Greek Coast Guard leaving asylum seekers at sea.
content: The European Commission has formally asked Greece to begin an investigation into a New York Times report based on exclusive footage showing the country’s Coast Guard abandoning migrants in the Aegean Sea last month, a top official said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus
title: The Moment They Knew: Escalating From Phone Calls to a Football Card
description: When Troy and Tommi Vincent made the jump from marathon phone calls to exchanging photos, there was one problem: The Miami Dolphins football card he sent her “wasn’t personal enough.”
content: After reconnecting via long-distance phone calls in the early 1990s, Tommi Vincent and Troy Vincent Sr., who had met a few years earlier in Trenton, N.J., decided it was time to exchange photos of each other through the mail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Traub
title: C. Boyden Gray, Lawyer for the Republican Establishment, Dies at 80
description: A former Democrat, he served as White House counsel under George Bush and aided other presidents, including Ronald Reagan and Donald J. Trump.
content: C. Boyden Gray, who personified the conservative legal establishment as a lawyer involved in judicial appointments, policy, diplomacy or fund-raising for every Republican president since Ronald Reagan, died on Sunday at his home in the Georgetown section of Washington. He was 80.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: 5 Things to Know About Tim Scott
description: Mr. Scott, who just announced a presidential campaign, is the first Black Republican senator from the South in more than a century and has been a prominent voice in his party on matters of race.
content: Senator Tim Scott of South Carolina, who announced his presidential campaign on Monday, is the first Black Republican senator from the South in more than a century and has been one of his party’s most prominent voices on matters of race, often navigating a political tightrope.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle
title: A Breakthrough Deal to Keep the Colorado River From Going Dry, for Now
description: The agreement on cuts, aided by a wet winter and $1.2 billion in federal payments, expires at the end of 2026.
content: Arizona, California and Nevada have agreed to take less water from the drought-strained Colorado River, a breakthrough agreement that, for now, keeps the river from falling so low that it would jeopardize water supplies for major Western cities like Phoenix and Los Angeles as well as for some of America’s most productive farmland.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: Airlines and F.A.A. Try to Head Off Summer Travel Meltdowns
description: Having angered travelers and lawmakers, airline executives and aviation officials said they were reducing flights, hiring staff and making other changes to avoid disruptions this summer.
content: The number of Americans who will fly this summer could eclipse the prepandemic high from 2019. That would be great news for airlines, but it could also cause a backlash against the industry if it fails to keep up with demand and delays or cancels thousands of flights.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin
title: NBCUniversal’s New Leader, a Hollywood Outsider, Steps Into the Spotlight
description: Mike Cavanagh, a veteran of the financial crisis, has just been given a leading part in the unending drama of Hollywood.
content: Mike Cavanagh couldn’t have picked a trickier time to take over NBCUniversal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: You Cannot Hear These 13 Women’s Stories and Believe the Anti-Abortion Narrative
description: If this isn’t what anti-abortion groups want, why won’t they fix it?
content: It’s increasingly clear that it’s not safe to be pregnant in states with total abortion bans. Since the end of Roe v. Wade, there have been a barrage of gutting stories about women in prohibition states denied care for miscarriages or forced to continue nonviable pregnancies. Though some in the anti-abortion movement publicly justify this sort of treatment, others have responded with a combination of denial, deflection and conspiracy theorizing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Eric Adams and the Migrants in New York
description: Contrasting views of how Mayor Adams is handling the influx. Also: Afghan exodus; aid to Ukraine; gender identity; horses’ deaths; the office and the commute.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Help! I Need a Guide to Shirt-Tucking Protocol.
description: Button-up shirts can be tucked, untucked, half-tucked or French tucked. A reader wonders where to begin.
content: So many ways to tuck, so hard to figure out which one is right! After all, tucking your shirt neatly into your waistband (or not) isn’t simply just about creating a silhouette. It’s a signifier that contains multitudes. Nowadays, you need to think before you tuck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Casselman
title: More Americans Are Struggling Financially, as Inflation Takes a Toll
description: A new Federal Reserve survey finds that the strong job market hasn’t been enough to offset the rising cost of living for many families.
content: Americans have jobs. They’re getting raises. And none of it is enough to keep up with the rising cost of living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priyanka Runwal
title: Scientists Find Brain Signals of Chronic Pain
description: A new study linked chronic pain to activity in the orbitofrontal cortex, an area involved in emotion regulation, self-evaluation and decision making.
content: Researchers have for the first time recorded the brain’s firing patterns while a person is feeling chronic pain, paving the way for implanted devices to one day predict pain signals or even short-circuit them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Remy Tumin
title: U.S. Investigates Fatal Shooting of Tribe Member by Border Agents
description: A member of the Tohono O’odham Nation was killed at his home on the reservation near the U.S.-Mexico border in Arizona, according to the authorities and local news reports.
content: The F.B.I. and federal border officials are investigating the fatal shooting last week of a member of the Tohono O’odham Nation by U.S. border agents on the reservation in Arizona near the U.S.-Mexico border, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Russia’s assertions of victory in Bakhmut.
content: Russia has claimed victory in the eastern Ukrainian city of Bakhmut. Though Moscow is trumpeting a “mission accomplished” moment, Ukraine insists that the city has not completely fallen. But while the deadliest battle of the war might be over, what comes next is far from clear.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur and John Liu
title: With Ban on Micron, China Escalates Microchip Clash With U.S.
description: A Chinese government block on Micron Technology’s memory chips marks how far apart the two economic powers are drifting on tech policy.
content: When cutting foreign technology companies from Chinese supply chains, Beijing has long chosen to work obliquely or even secretly. Regulators would give executives back-room lectures, weigh them down with excessive red tape or hit them with occasional office raids. Rarely did the government tell a firm outright it was no longer welcome.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: Columns That Scrutinized, and Skewered, the Literary World
description: “NB by J.C.” collects the variegated musings of James Campbell in the Times Literary Supplement.
content: If you are a subscriber to the Times Literary Supplement, or TLS, that august literary review out of London, you know that its good, gray issues roll in every week, more quickly than it is possible to keep up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Cacciola
title: Jimmy Butler, the Smiling Villain, Has the Celtics on the Ropes
description: Butler has shaped the Miami Heat in his no-quit, self-assured image, which is bad news for a reeling Boston team that is one loss from elimination in the Eastern Conference finals.
content: MIAMI — For much of Game 3 of the N.B.A.’s Eastern Conference finals on Sunday, Jimmy Butler did something he does not often do: He played a supporting role. He created off the dribble, zipped passes to his Heat teammates for open shots and pushed to score only when the opportunity made too much sense not to seize it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: Why Bakhmut? It’s a Question as Old as War.
description: The twists and turns of a war are rarely easy to predict. In Ukraine, they landed on a city in the east that few had ever heard of. And then the whole world watched for months.
content: Just weeks before President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine visited the city of Bakhmut in December, a soldier with the military call sign “Bear” stared out from the window of a ruined sixth-floor apartment overlooking the city’s eastern reaches. I quietly stood next to him. The battle below played out in muted ferocity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Make-Ahead Salads That Stay Fresh and Flavorful
description: Potato salad is bright with chives, lemon and snappy green beans; summer’s first tomatoes marinate in a garlicky soy vinaigrette.
content: Spring has been bashful this year in the Northeast, beaming with sunshine one minute, only to cover up with sheets of clouds and dampening rain the next. But, as Kay Chun reminds us, summer is just around the corner, “ready to encourage breezy communal dining under the glow of the sun and the grill,” she writes in her lovely article in The New York Times.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Listen to The Headlines, Our New Audio Front Page
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app includes podcasts, narrated articles from the newsroom and other publishers, as well as exclusive new shows — including this one — which we’re making available to readers for a limited time. Download the audio app here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Neff, Alysia Santo and Tom Meagher
title: How a ‘Blue Wall’ Inside N.Y. State Prisons Protects Abusive Guards
description: Records and interviews reveal a culture of cover-ups among correction officers who falsify reports and send beating victims to solitary confinement.
content: The way the prison guards described it in their paperwork, there was a minor disturbance the day they took Chad Stanbro to a dental clinic at a regional hospital.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Justin Porter and Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Bakhmut in Ruins
description: Plus, China bans some U.S. chips.
content: Ukraine has tacitly acknowledged that Russia has seized Bakhmut: A Ukrainian official said today that Russian forces are engaged in “mopping up” operations to clear the remaining Ukrainian soldiers in the city — even as Kyiv seeks to shift the focus from the apparent loss to the battle for the city’s outskirts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: M.T.A. Proposes Raising Bus and Subway Fares to $2.90 by Summer’s End
description: The proposed increase would be the first in the base fare since 2015 and would raise the price of a seven-day MetroCard by a dollar.
content: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority on Monday proposed raising the base fare for a single New York City subway, bus or paratransit ride 5 percent, to $2.90 from $2.75 — the first increase to the base fare since 2015.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Brooks
title: Tim Keller Taught Me About Joy
description: He was a guide to a wonder-filled life.
content: Tim Keller was a recliner. Whenever a particular group of my friends would get together, discussing some personal, social or philosophical issue over Zoom during the past few years, you could see Tim just chilling and enjoying it, lounging back in his chair. The conversation would flow, and finally somebody would ask: “Tim, what do you think?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: With Bakhmut in Ruins, Ukraine Shifts Focus
description: Also, a deal to protect the Colorado River. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: The eastern city of Bakhmut, site of the longest and bloodiest battle of the war in Ukraine, is almost entirely obliterated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky
title: Deadly Fire at Guyana Dormitory Was Deliberately Set, Official Says
description: Many of the 19 victims were schoolchildren. The fire service said it was still unclear who had set the building ablaze.
content: A fire that engulfed a girls’ dormitory at a school overnight in central Guyana and killed at least 19 people, many of them children, had been “maliciously set,” a fire service official said on Monday, as the authorities in the South American country scrambled for answers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Bioré and Influencer Apologize After School Shooting Ad
description: A Michigan State graduate apologized after she talked about how the school shooting there affected her mental health as part of a paid partnership with the beauty company.
content: The skin care brand Bioré apologized this week after facing criticisms that a paid social media post advertising its products at once trivialized and exploited the issue of gun violence in America.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman and Maya King
title: Tim Scott Begins Presidential Campaign, Adding to List of Trump Challengers
description: The South Carolina senator added his positive, aspirational message to a growing and fractious Republican primary field. He enters the race having raised $22 million.
content: Tim Scott, the first Black Republican elected to the Senate from the South since Reconstruction, announced his campaign for president on Monday, bringing a positive, aspirational message to a growing field of Republicans running as alternatives to former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Leitch
title: Trump Is Back, to Make Families Fight Again
description: Families across America that were so divided by the Trump era have only started to heal — and now we’re facing the real possibility of a sequel.
content: My cousin back in rural Illinois, where I grew up and where most of my family still lives, sent me a nice note over Facebook the other day. She saw I had a novel coming out and told me she was proud of me and couldn’t wait to read it. I thanked her and said I’d love to catch lunch the next time I’m in town. She said that would be nice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: An Oil Refiner Leans on Manure to Provide a Greener Future
description: Varo Energy, a Swiss provider of gasoline and diesel, is charting a path to lower carbon energy by relying on farm waste and used cooking oil.
content: Every day dozens of tanker trucks, many laden with pig manure and other kinds of agricultural waste, rumble through the gateway of an imposing steel-and-concrete plant in northeast Netherlands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: Vinícius Júnior Says Racism Is ‘Normal’ in Spanish Soccer
description: After Valencia fans called the Real Madrid star a monkey, Spain’s top soccer official called racial abuse a stain on the entire country.
content: Vinícius Júnior has had enough.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Nashville Parents Ask: Must a Mass Shooter’s Writings Be Made Public?
description: The lack of information about what motivated a deadly attack on a Christian school has led to a protracted legal fight over releasing the shooter’s handwritten journals.
content: Barely two months after an armed assailant fatally shot three children and three adults at a private Christian school in Nashville, the lack of information about the motive has led to a bitter legal fight over whether handwritten journals and writings found during a search of the shooter’s home and car should be released to the public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Ronen Bergman
title: He Was Investigating Mexico’s Military. Then the Spying Began.
description: While looking into abuses by the armed forces, the country’s top human rights official was targeted with Pegasus, the world’s most notorious spyware, The Times found.
content: He is a longtime friend of the president, a close political ally for decades who is now the government’s top human rights official.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Moser
title: Did She Cheat? A Century Later, a Novel’s Mystery Still Stumps.
description: “Dom Casmurro,” by Machado de Assis, teaches us to read — and reread — with precise detail and masterly obfuscation.
content: It is one of the mysteries of my life as a reader that I did not, at first, like Machado de Assis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: When TV Becomes a Window Into Women’s Rage
description: Over the last few years, TV has offered portraits of female rage that are striking within a culture that still prefers women to carry their anger calmly and silently.
content: In art, the image of the enraged woman often represents an ugly, almost talismanic evil: In Adolphe-William Bouguereau’s 1862 painting “Orestes Pursued by the Furies,” the women sneer, brandishing weapons at Orestes. In Artemisia Gentileschi’s “Judith Slaying Holofernes,” Judith furrows her brow, half of her face cloaked in shadow, and clutches a fistful of Holofernes’s hair as she plunges a sword into his neck. And Caravaggio’s Medusa, a wronged woman transformed into a monster, is just a severed head, and yet her face is animated with fury, mouth open in a scream, brows creased.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: May 22, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, May 22, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Don Clark
title: Silicon Valley, Cradle of Computer Chips, Gains Big New Research Center
description: Anticipating federal subsidies, Applied Materials said it planned to invest up to $4 billion in the semiconductor project in Sunnyvale, Calif.
content: Silicon Valley got its name from computer chips, but no longer plays a central role in shaping how they are made. A major supplier to the industry hopes to change that.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport and Catie Edmondson
title: Debt Limit Negotiators Debate Spending Caps to Break Standoff
description: The strategy, which was used in 2011, could allow both sides to save face but would most likely do little to chip away at the national debt.
content: As negotiators for the White House and House Republican leaders struggle to reach a deal over how to raise the nation’s debt limit, a solution that harks back to old budget fights has re-emerged as a potential path forward: spending caps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Meta Fined $1.3 Billion for Violating E.U. Data Privacy Rules
description: The Facebook owner said it would appeal an order to stop sending data about European Union users to the United States.
content: Meta on Monday was fined a record 1.2 billion euros ($1.3 billion) and ordered to stop transferring data collected from Facebook users in Europe to the United States, in a major ruling against the social media company for violating European Union data protection rules.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joseph Goldstein
title: Resident Doctors Go on Strike at Elmhurst Hospital in Queens
description: The strike, the first by doctors in New York City since 1990, shows how the pandemic may be leading to rising activism among young doctors.
content: More than 150 trainee doctors went on strike Monday at Elmhurst Hospital Center in Queens, the first physician strike at a hospital in New York City in more than 30 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: Nikola Jokic Has Mastered the Art of Slowness
description: Providing unhurried but timely play, Jokic, the two-time most valuable player, has the Denver Nuggets on the cusp of the N.B.A. finals.
content: LOS ANGELES — After watching Nikola Jokic repeatedly lumber down the court, hold a basketball above the defense like a freshly picked grapefruit, wheel, pause, and sling a tightrope pass that led a teammate to an open shot, a question came to mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Imogen West-Knights
title: In Its Final Season, ‘Happy Valley’ Grapples With Healing
description: The BAFTA-winning crime drama returns with its characters seven years older and continuing to confront generational trauma and grief.
content: At the end of Season 2 of “Happy Valley,” Catherine Cawood (Sarah Lancashire) watches her 9-year-old grandson Ryan running up a hill, thrashing at the grass with a stick. Her expression is grave, and Ryan’s father is in prison for murder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval, J. David Goodman and Tamir Kalifa
title: A Year After a School Shooting, Divisions Run Through Uvalde
description: Tensions have flared over new rifts between victims’ families and the police, and between gun owners and newly minted gun-control activists.
content: At a school board meeting this month in Uvalde, Texas, parents and administrators found themselves locked in what had become a familiar argument: Nearly a year had passed since a gunman breached Robb Elementary School and killed 19 children and two teachers. The community was still waiting for officials to fully disclose how it happened.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Naveen Kumar
title: Review: In ‘Bees & Honey,’ Love Is Both Sweet and Sticky
description: In this play by Guadalís Del Carmen, a couple’s shared heritage is integral to their meeting and the ups and downs of their daily relationship.
content: What draws two lovers together may be more obvious than what keeps them in sync. An inviting smile and smooth opening line can pierce the noise of a crowded club, but then what? In the case of “Bees & Honey,” which opened at MCC Theater on Monday, eyes lock and hips swivel to the plucky guitar and eight-count beat of bachata.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of May 15, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Hawthorne
title: Radical Rethinking at Biennale: Africa and the Future Share Pride of Place
description: Don’t be fooled by its generic title. Lesley Lokko’s “Laboratory of the Future” is the most ambitious and pointedly political Venice Architecture Biennale in years.
content: VENICE — It is rare enough for a Venice Architecture Biennale, so often dominated by sleek new architecture and design-world celebrity, to confront fraught subjects like race, colonialism and climate change. Lesley Lokko’s nervy, elegant edition, which opened to the public on Saturday, goes one step further, asserting that the three themes are inextricably connected in ways that have pressing implications for the profession.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Working From Home and Realizing What Matters
description: Reduced commuting won’t raise G.D.P. So what?
content: The U.S. economy has experienced a remarkable recovery from the Covid recession of 2020. The much-feared scarring effects of the pandemic never materialized: Employment, labor force participation and gross domestic product are right back in line with projections made before the pandemic struck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Shanahan
title: He Freed an Innocent Man From Prison. It Ruined His Life.
description: Jay Salpeter cracked a high-profile case to help exonerate Martin Tankleff. It was a blessing and a curse. For both of them.
content: Flashes flashed and shutters snapped as an exuberant crowd focused its attention on Martin Tankleff.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Alert Level Is Raised in Central Mexico as Volcano Spews Smoke and Ash
description: Officials were preparing evacuation routes and shelters around the volcano, Popocatépetl, and some schools and parks were closed to minimize exposure to falling ash.
content: An alert level was raised on Sunday for a volcano in Central Mexico that was spewing ash and smoke, prompting officials to close schools and public parks, and to prepare for the possibility of evacuations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan and Daniel Dorsa
title: She’s Out to Save Rare Wildflowers, but First She Has to Find Them
description: A wet winter has provided a narrow window for botanists to search for wildflowers that have been lying dormant for years in California.
content: The white Toyota Tacoma bumped along the dirt path, up and down hills, brush scratching the sides of the truck with a high-pitched whine. Naomi Fraga, her hair in pigtail braids under a ball cap, drove like a slightly more cautious Indiana Jones guided by an ancient map.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sapna Cheryan and Therese Anne Mortejo
title: The Most Common Graduation Advice Tends to Backfire
description: “Follow your passions”? Not so fast.
content: As American high school and college students graduate and embark on the next phases of their lives, one piece of advice they will undoubtedly receive is to follow their passions or some equivalent sentiment. It seems like fine guidance, however clichéd: Do something that feels true to yourself rather than conform to expectations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: Being Born in the Hamptons Is One Thing. Staying Is Quite Another.
description: The housing market remains way out of reach for locals who want to live, work and raise a family in their hometowns.
content: Robyn Diederiks-Henderson grew up in Montauk, N.Y., waiting tables at her mom’s restaurants. Her longtime boyfriend and husband of two years, Dylan Henderson, was born and raised down the road in Southampton.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Schwirtz and Marc Santora
title: Russia Claims Bakhmut, but Some See a ‘Pyrrhic Victory’
description: A top Ukrainian official essentially acknowledged that the devastated city had been lost. Thousands of Ukrainian and Russian soldiers died there, but the cost for Moscow was especially steep, experts say.
content: It took the Kremlin almost a year and cost the lives of thousands of soldiers to capture Bakhmut, but now that Russian forces appear to have control of the Ukrainian city, it is fair to question the value of what they have gained.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Belarus Pardons Opposition Activist Who Was Hauled Off a Ryanair Flight, State Media Says
description: Roman Protasevich had been sentenced to eight years in prison. The details of his 2021 arrest drew international attention.
content: Belarus has pardoned an opposition activist who was arrested in 2021 after the Belarusian government forced the landing of a commercial flight he had been on that was transiting its airspace, state media reported on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin and Zachary Small
title: 5 Takeaways From Auction Week
description: Amid high inflation and low inventory, the art market correction appears to have landed. If it wasn’t a trophy, it probably struggled to command a high price.
content: Spring auction week tends to be a swirl of heartachingly beautiful works of art and mind-bendingly big prices. But it also serves a more practical purpose: setting the level of the art market. Is it strong overall or ailing? Were prices inflated, appropriate or low? Which artists broke out and which tanked?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Grenade Detonation Kills Father and Injures His Two Children
description: The family had been going through a grandfather’s belongings when they found the explosive device, the authorities said.
content: An Indiana father was killed and his two children were injured after they went through a grandfather’s belongings and found a hand grenade that detonated at a family home on Saturday, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. D. Biersdorfer
title: Can You Guess This Award-Winning Author and Screenwriter?
description: This Nobel Prize-winning author has had several novels adapted for film and television. Do you know who it is?
content: This Nobel Prize-winning author has had several novels adapted for film and television. Do you know who it is?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Marchese
title: Want to Live Longer and Healthier? Peter Attia Has a Plan.

title: Greek PM Greets Supporters After Election Victory, Seeks Majority
